abstract.text: 4 The SARS-CoV-2 virus causing the global pandemic is a coronavirus with a 5 genome of about 30Kbase length. The design of vaccines and choice of therapies 6 depends on the structure and mutational stability of encoded proteins in the open 7 reading frames(ORFs) of this genome. In this study, we computed, using Expectation 8 Reflection, the genome-wide covariation of the SARS-CoV-2 genome based on an 9 alignment of ≈ 130000 SARS-CoV-2 complete genome sequences obtained from 10 GISAID. We used this covariation to compute the Direct Information between pairs of 11 positions across the whole genome, investigating potentially important relationships 12 within the genome, both within each encoded protein and between encoded proteins. 13 We then computed the covariation within each clade of the virus. The covariation 14 detected recapitulates all clade determinants and each clade exhibits distinct covarying 15 pairs.

FIGREF0.text: Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is a viral respiratory disease caused by the 19 SARS-associated coronavirus. In December 2019, this pneumonia-like disease re-emerged 20 in the Chinese city of Wuhan and the novel beta-coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) was iden-21 tified as the causative agent [Zhu et al., 2020]. The genome was first characterized by 22 Wu et al. in December 2019 [Wu et al., 2020]. Since then the SARS-CoV-2 virus has 23 spread relentlessly all over the world and been declared a worldwide pandemic with 24 79 million cases leading to 1.7 million deaths to date [World Health Organization, 2020, 25 John Hopkins University, 2020]. SARS-CoV-2 is an +ssRNA virus belonging to the coron-26 aviridae family major genera Betacoronavirus [Gorbalenya et al., 2020]. The viral genome 27 encodes several open reading frames (ORFs): ORF1ab, ORF3a, ORF6, ORF7a, ORF7b, 28 ORF8, ORF10. These ORFs encode for several non-structural proteins (NSPs) while 29 there are specific regions encoding the spike glycoprotein (S), envelope (E), membrane 30 glycoprotein (M), and the nucleocapsid protein (N). With the first viral entry on January 39 10 2020, the database has grown to 292,000 submissions [Shu & McCauley, 2017]. In our analysis of the SARS 278 CoV-2 genome we have presented several perspectives on nucleotide interactions in the 279 genome. These interactions showed both proximal interactions within individual encod-280 ing regions as well as distal interactions between different encoding regions throughout 281 the genome. We inferred nucleotide position interactions for the entire genome as well 282 as the separate encoding regions. Particular attention was given to the ORF1ab and S 283 regions, which demonstrated the highest variability in the given dataset. We were able 284 to draw analogous conclusions from previous work by inferring the the most common 285 variations previously reported [Uğurel et al., 2020]. Additionally, our genome-wide inter-286 action maps expressed determinant positions of all clades available at the time our data was 287 acquired [Mercatelli & Giorgi, 2020]. Generating interaction maps of individual clades 288 showed clade-specific coevolution of nucleotide positions. 289 We further considered the level of variability, both within regions of the full genome 290 data set and for different clades. This was accomplished by varying the threshold for 291 conserved columns while considering the retained column incidence. This relationship 292 shows nucleotide variability is different both between encoding regions of the full genome 293 and between different clades. Region-specific incidences are not consistent between clades, 294 with individual regions expressing different variability in different clades. Comparison of 295 region-specific incidence can also give intuition on the level of variability or specific regions 296 within specific clades. 297 Our work shares significant similarities in results with the work of Zeng et al. [Zeng et al., 2020] 298 in which 50000 SARS-CoV-2 genomes were analysed using pseudo-likelihood maximiza-299 tion [Ekeberg et al., 2014]. We inferred 5 of the 8 epistatic links described in their work with 300 the notable exception of not inferring 3 interaction pairs: (17858, 18060), (17747, 17858) 301 and (17747, 18060) in the ORF1ab region. This exclusion is likely due to the larger data-set 302 used in our analysis as those links were removed during post-processing due to insignificant 303 DI scoring (< .1). Another notable difference between the results and methodology of 304 this work and that of [Zeng et al., 2020] is in the consideration of inherited significance. 305 It should be noted that phylogenetic statistical analysis is a deep subject and there is a 306 great deal of subtlety regarding the applicability of simple approaches like randomiza-307 tion [Martins & Hansen, 1996]. [Zeng et al., 2020] utilize phylogenetic randomization to 308 filter out insignificant inferences that arise only due to phylogenetic relationships. We 309 simply use data-driven clade stratification to remove such effects. This stratification in turn 310 yields novel sets of interactions which are clade specific and therefore are unlikely to be 311 influenced by shared inheritance. In the absence of clade determinant positions however, 312 the use of phylogenetic randomization by [Zeng et al., 2020] would be necessary. 4 Materials and Methods 321 4.1 Ising model covariation analysis 322 We use the standard Ising model analogy first applied to protein sequences by Lapedes et 323 al [Lapedes et al., 2012]. This basic method has been applied by many groups with small 324 refinements on how the couplings of the Ising model are actually computed. We formulated 325 the Ising model coupling calculation in terms of logistic regression with one-hot encoding of 326 the genome sequences. As there is no closed form solution to logistic regression problems, 327 essentially all methods for finding coefficients are iterative. The particular algorithm we 328 used to find the logistic regression coefficients was Expectation Reflection which has been 329 demonstrated to perform well in the limit of for small sample sizes [Hoang et al., 2019b], 330 but the results do not differ appreciably from logistic regression with regularization as im-331 plemented in the Scikit-learn Python package, for example.
